Holiday Break = Monopoly (Logically) üòÇ

Ahhh, it‚Äôs that time of year again - a break from work, and some time with the family.

For my family at least, that sometimes means playing Monopoly! (What other time of year do you have 4+ hours to spend duking it out with one of the world‚Äôs most loved1 games?)

So, anyway, my brother had snagged both the purples (Mediterranean and Baltic) and the light blues (, and Connecticut) . When a player owns both of these adjacent monopolies, we cherishingly call that player the ‚Äòslum lord‚Äô). My girlfriend ended up with the greens and blues, what we call the ‚Äòhigh roller‚Äô properties. I of course, thought she had the better advantage of winning. But as the game went on, we realized just how high maintenance (the properties, not my girlfriend üòÇ) those expensive are. First, they cost a fortune to buy, and at $200 dollars per house. In addition, Boardwalk and Park Place have the added fact that they are only a 2 property set.

In the end, my girlfriend was one of the first players to go out, while my brother lasted as 2nd place in the game (I actually ended up winning due to massive luck with the purple properties (Virginia, States, and St. Charles Place))

So, now the question: was our intuition with higher or lower prof? Or is it true that some properties and property groups have an inherently better profit margin?

Turns out, it couldn‚Äôt be more true!
